From TSLA earnings call slides: Volume: Our company is currently between two major growth waves: the first one began with the global expansion of the Model 3/Y platform and we believe the next one will be initiated by advances in autonomy and introduction of new products, including those built on our next generation vehicle platform. Despite ongoing macroeconomic conditions, we expect to achieve slight growth in vehicle deliveries in 2024.

from TER Q3 2024 transcript: In Memory, AI-driven HBM DRAM demand remains very strong and AI servers are driving demand for enterprise SSD NAND flash. Our memory business is at record levels, driven by volume shipments for DRAM wafer store and HBM stack die test. We are revising our estimated Memory TAM expectation for the year to approximately $1.4 billion, above our prior estimate range of 1.2 to 1.3. The Memory Test for TAM in 2024 is now expected to be over 35% higher than the last peak in 2021. We note that the 2024 Memory TAM includes a big slug of initial tooling for HBM...

I bought AEHR thinking they could be an AI play, realized they aren't, then, sold it at a loss, bought something going up, made my money back.  But I keep watching AEHR to see if, other than a day-trade, it's worth holding.  Where will the growth come from?  I'm looking at a trailing PE of 15 which is great, but a forward PE of 31.  That's the wrong direction.  I really don't see this stock doing anything but settling back to 12 until they announce a great thing that will move the forward PE in the right direction.  What am I missing. I want a reason to buy this again, but I can't find any, other than a short squeeze, which, without fundamentals, is just a Gamestop play that can cut your fingers by holding.  A few insiders buying at a discount of 10.50 doesn't tempt me.  Especially with other chip sector stocks, or even holding an ETF like Vanguard Information Technology Index Fund (VGT) for the last 6 months you'd be so much wealthier.  Would like to hear valid reasons... not "short squeeze coming" or "maybe AI".

Looks like the After Hours action got spooked by the filed S3. Aehr mentioned that in the conference call so that was not a surprise but maybe the amount was a surprise which was listed as $100 Million (I think the last one used $75 million) But these are just filings in case they decide to raise money in the future. It doesnt mean they are going to raise 1 dime. They need to be renewed every three years. No big deal but obviously in todays environment a reason to push it down another 40 cents after hours.

The offering is just a re-upping of their previous shelf offering that expired, they havn’t actually sold shares.

Fiscal First Quarter Financial Results:Net revenue was $13.1 million, compared to $20.6 million in the first quarter of fiscal 2024.GAAP net income was $0.7 million, or $0.02 per diluted share, compared to GAAP net income of $4.7 million, or $0.16 per diluted share, in the first quarter of fiscal 2024.Non-GAAP net income, which excludes the impact of stock-based compensation, acquisition-related costs, and amortization of intangible assets, was $2.2 million, or $0.07 per diluted share, compared to non-GAAP net income of $5.2 million, or $0.18 per diluted share, in the first quarter of fiscal 2024.Bookings were $16.8 million for the quarter.Backlog as of August 30, 2024 was $16.6 million.Total cash, cash equivalents and restricted cash as of August 30, 2024 were $40.8 million, compared to $49.3 million at May 31, 2024, reflecting $10.6 million in net cash paid during the quarter for the acquisition of Incal Technology, Inc.An explanation of the use of non-GAAP financial measures and a reconciliation of Aehr's non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures can be found in the accompanying tables.

The quarter is over and no additional announcements. The estimates have been about 1 cent in earnings and $12 million in revenues for quarter ending August 31. Effective backlog in July was about $20.8 million which included the $12.8 million order which was supposed to ship in the next three months when announced and based on the math they gave in the report there is still another 700k which appears to be unannounced backlog in effective backlog which would make total of that portion at $13.5 million. So assuming they shipped half of that, 6.75M, and most of the $7.3 million that was on the books June 1st. Let’s just say 6M. So 6.75 plus 6.0 plus 1 million of Incal is about $13.75 million which should beat estimates and make sure earnings greater than 1 cent. Now the problem is that this quarter which begin September 1st, the estimates are $16.5 million for revenues. If my estimates are close for the past quarter, Aehr will still have $8 million revenues in backlog just to start this quarter ending November 30th with most all of it likely shipping this quarter. Now we just need to build on this and get some Orders to make that $16.5 and get some spring into the next quarter.

Just like SiC power chips, substandard photonic chips must be eliminated from the manufacturing process. Burn-in also helps stabilize these devices before final installation in an AI system. Aehr may be sitting on another growth outlet.

Aehr CEO Gayn Erickson explained that testing photonics in AI chips could be a big market for Aehr in the not-too-distant future. Erickson said in the latest earnings call that six customers are using Aehr equipment to produce photonics tests in AI devices.

To be clear, there is no firm timeline for when silicon photonics will become a viable market for Aehr's equipment. However, as AI systems consume more data and power, tiny silicon photonics (which uses lasers to speed up data transmission between chips) could help solve data bottlenecks in these complex devices

Infineon's Q3 FY24 earnings call transcript came out today.  Opening remarks acknowledged healthy consumer demand in China, but tepid Western markets. They confirmed a SiC revenue target of 600 million euros this fiscal year, up 20% from last year, but then the CEO seemed to walk that back a bit in Q&A.  Kulim 3 (200 mm SiC fab/module) will "open" this week and slowly ramp as determined by customer demand.  There was an interesting question asked about VW (referring to ON's recent PR announcing Onsemi as the primary supplier for VW's SCC Platform).  SiC device prices are dropping - which is normal for improving economics as the shift to 200mm wafers takes place.  Infineon now is offering "fusion" modules that combine silicon and SiC power devices and already has collected two design wins. It's hard to predict what this means for AEHR sales to IFNNY in AEHR's FY25.  Maybe one more XP with fully integrated and automated aligner.  And a bunch of Waferpaks.

For decades, silicon has been the main material of electronics, but in the continuous path towards miniaturization it seems destined to be abandoned soon due to some of its intrinsic limitations. To be able to control a series of physical phenomena useful in some new sectors, such as photonics, it would be necessary to be able to model the inside of thin sheets of silicon at nanometric dimensions. An objective that has so far been impossible, so much so that it has prompted the search for possible substitutes for silicon. However, even the possible candidate materials present various obstacles. The new technique, which uses very short laser pulses, allows us to engrave thin layers (silicon wafers) with great precision, reaching dimensions 10 times smaller than what has been possible so far, reaching 100 nanometres. The technique which, the researchers observe , can be applied on relatively large surfaces and in a very efficient way. It could therefore pave the way for new applications of silicon and the most interesting ones, according to Tokel “could concern photonics, in particular metamaterials and photonic crystals”.
The doors are open to use silicon in ways that were previously impossible Thanks to lasers capable of digging inside it on a nanoscale
